awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Cellular Bioengineering -- From Biomaterials to Stem Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
The REU Site: Cellular Bioengineering -- From Biomaterials to Stem Cells offers students exciting research projects that introduce them to a broad array of topics grounded in Cellular Bioengineering. Cellular Bioengineering encompasses a number of cutting edge research fields and articulates with nanotechnology, advanced materials, systems biology and stem cells. Training undergraduate students with diverse backgrounds in Cellular Bioengineering will broaden the research base and lead to an expanded and better-trained workforce in this rapidly expanding field. Program elements in innovation, entrepreneurship, and translational research enhance the students' marketable skill set and increase the potential for their current and future discoveries to be converted to technological advances of great impact. Unlike the traditional research that undergraduates typically conduct, the REU Site program is leveraging broad-based training through engineering projects that additionally integrate efforts across the life sciences and physical sciences. The recruitment efforts specifically target individuals who normally have limited research opportunities, including those from underrepresented groups and from colleges without substantial graduate research and training. The program expects to expand the pipeline of students entering graduate programs, by helping to engage a group who would likely have not considered graduate school. 

The REU Site is employing standardized elements of research training and professional development to accelerate the students' learning curve and inoculate them into active laboratories that are pursuing high-impact Cellular Bioengineering research. The program is employing active mentoring, collaboration, and regular monitoring of the students to achieve its goals. Project areas that the students will work on include: 1) Multi-modal cues for phenotypic control of neural cells, 2) Polymer nanoformulations for delivery of macromolecular therapeutics, 3) High Throughput, Automated, Single Cell Electroporation, 4) Encapsulated MSC Regulation of Inflammatory Environments, 5) Cell and tissue engineering approaches to tendon and ligament healing, 6) Reprogrammed Stem Cells and 3-D Microenvironments, 7) High Throughput Platform for Drug Metabolism Screening in Fatty Liver Cells, 8) Interactions of lipid-based nanocarriers with vascular endothelia and macrophages, 9) Designing Scaffold Cues for Retinal Pigment Epithelial Tissue Engineering, 10) Subcellular structural dynamics and mechanotransduction to branching neurons, and 11) Non-destructive measurement of tissue morphomechanical properties. A Cellular Bioengineering Boot Camp introduces participants to laboratory and imaging skills that accelerates their integration into their research labs. A focus on Innovation and Entrepreneurship parallels the recent NSF I-Corps initiative for translational research to capitalize on the potential for new technology that emanates from the research. A component of the program is a clinical immersion, where the REU scholars will observe clinicians in the surgical unit. The Scholars use these experiences to identify needs and problems and brainstorm about innovations and technologies to solve these problems. Under the guidance of faculty from the Center for Innovative Ventures of Emerging Technologies, the students build business plans around these ideas. Weekly seminars and discussion groups allow tracking and monitoring of the Scholars' experiences while concurrently engaging them in professional development. Incorporation of a mentoring workshop for the graduate students who serve as "near-peer" mentors further broadens the impact of the program.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
Rutgers has continuously operated the Cellular Bioengineering: From Biomaterials to Stem Cells REU Site since 2010 and completed its second project period from 2016-2021. In total, 116 scholars have participated in the REU, including 48 during this award. The mission of the program is to provide opportunities for immersive research in cutting edge techniques in biomedical engineering and biotechnology as well as strong mentoring and professional development. The program is particularly focused on providing these opportunities to students with backgrounds that are traditionally underrepresented in STEM research. Towards this goal, of the 116 scholars: 54 were under-represented minorities; 63 were women; 44 were in the 1st generation of their family to attend college; and 66 were from primarily undergraduate institutions, which do not offer immersive research experiences. These students hailed from 8 different institutions representing 34 different states and territories.  

 

Students were mentored by faculty in Biomedical Engineering and conducted research in project areas including nanoengineering, tissue engineering, cellular engineering, systems biology, BioMEMS, drug delivery, and imaging. With partial support from the REU program, students have delivered 64 scientific presentations at a variety of national and state meetings, and have been co-authors on 13 peer-reviewed publications.  Five conference presentations have been delivered by the program directors describing program elements of training and professional development. The REU site includes a programmatic emphasis on Innovation & Entrepreneurship. Each summer, the REU students split into 3 groups and complete exercises to identify, develop, and commercialize a product based on their research. In this project period, a one-day clinical immersion was added, where the cohort met with various clinicians at Robert Wood Johnson Medical School to identify opportunities for innovation. Separate weekly activities focus on written and oral communication and emphasize proposal preparation. Research and business pitches is presented at an end-of-summer symposium.

The REU in Cellular Bioengineering also partners with other summer STEM programs at Rutgers to offer weekly larger group workshops that again focus on professional development, such as career panels, ethics discussions, and global health. A specific goal is to allow these students - who have expressed a desire to pursue graduate studies – the opportunity to experience research at the graduate level and provide guidance in that decision as well as how to select schools and program and improve their likelihood of admission. Of 116 participants in the Cellular Bioengineering REU - 103 of whom have completed their undergraduate studies -  Of those 75% continued with their education in one form or another, and 70% entered graduate school for a masters, doctorate, or MD-PhD. Specifically, 57 of the 103 students who have participated in the Cellular Bioengineering REU and have graduated from their undergraduate institution have pursued doctoral studies. Of these 57, 10 have been awarded the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship. This success rate, along with individual testimonials, demonstrates the success of the program. 

Intellectual Merit: Students in the REU in Cellular Bioengineering participate in cutting-edge research at the forefront of biomedical engineering and biotechnology and have assisted in making new discoveries and developing new technologies, as demonstrated by the presentations and publications. Exercises is Innovation & Entrepreneurship, including clinical immersion experiences, contribute to the students’ understanding and appreciation for translational research. In addition, “best practices” in training, such as the Cellular Bioengineering Boot Camp, have been developed to address the challenge of quickly integrating relative neophytes with little training into the research environment of a major university, as well as facilitating these students’ professional development.

Broader Impact: The research completed by the students was broadly disseminated at state and national conferences and through peer-reviewed publications. The programmatic elements were similarly disseminated. A large majority of the participants have continued to pursue graduate degrees, and many are now starting their own careers. Participants have enjoyed great success in fellowships and awards. The program also provided a valuable vehicle for graduate students to participate as “near peer” mentors. The program has been very successful in impacting a number of different populations of students and has also enjoyed great geographic diversity.

 


Last Modified: 02/22/2022
Modified by: David I Shreiber
